questions.question: Which of the following is the fundamental requirement for a molecule to exhibit geometric (cis-trans) isomerism?
options: Restricted rotation around a bond and two different groups on each carbon of the double bond
The presence of at least one triple bond
Four identical groups attached to the double bond
A minimum of six carbon atoms in the parent chain
questions.explanation: Geometric isomerism requires restricted rotation (usually a double bond) and that each carbon involved in the bond is attached to two distinct groups.

questions.question: In a 'cis' isomer of an alkene, where are the identical or high-priority groups located relative to the double bond?
options: On the same side of the double bond
On opposite sides of the double bond
Attached to the same carbon atom
At a 180Â° angle from each other
questions.explanation: The term 'cis' comes from Latin meaning 'on this side,' indicating the groups are on the same side of the plane.

questions.question: Which molecule can exist as a pair of geometric isomers?
questions.explanation: In but-2-ene, each double-bonded carbon has a hydrogen and a methyl group. In but-1-ene and 2-methylpropene, one of the carbons has two identical groups (hydrogens or methyls), which prevents geometric isomerism.

questions.question: When the groups on the double bond are all different, which naming system is used to assign configuration based on atomic number priority?
questions.explanation: The E-Z system uses Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority rules to handle complex alkenes where cis-trans labels are ambiguous.

questions.question: In the E-Z system, if the two groups of higher priority are on opposite sides of the double bond, the isomer is labeled as:
According to the Cahn-Ingold-Prelog (CIP) priority rules, which atom would have the highest priority?
questions.explanation: Priority is assigned based on the atomic number; the higher the atomic number, the higher the priority.

questions.question: How do the physical properties of cis and trans isomers typically compare?
options: They have different physical properties such as boiling points and melting points
They only differ in their molecular mass
questions.explanation: Because they have different spatial arrangements, their dipole moments and packing efficiency differ, leading to different boiling and melting points.

questions.question: Why does trans-but-2-ene typically have a higher melting point than cis-but-2-ene?
options: The trans isomer is more symmetrical and packs better in a crystal lattice
The trans isomer is more polar
The trans isomer has more carbon atoms
The cis isomer has stronger covalent bonds
questions.explanation: High symmetry in trans isomers leads to better packing in the solid state, requiring more energy to break the lattice.

questions.question: A molecule is named (Z)-1-bromo-1-chloroprop-1-ene. Where are the highest priority groups located?
options: On the same side of the double bond
On opposite sides of the double bond
questions.explanation: (Z) stands for 'zusammen' (German for 'together'), meaning the high-priority groups are on the same side.

questions.question: Which of the following can be considered a 'stereoisomer'?
questions.explanation: Stereoisomers have the same bond connectivity but different arrangements of atoms in space. Geometric isomers are a type of stereoisomer.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You clearly understand the spatial requirements of alkene isomers.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You can distinguish between E/Z and cis/trans configurations.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing the priority rules for E/Z nomenclature.
scoreMessages.0: Review the requirement for restricted rotation and group distinctness.
